questions.text: The longest fetal diameter is?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Mentovertical diameter

 

  • Mentovertical diameter is the longest fetal diameter
  • It is seen when the presenting part is the brow

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A: Biparietal diameter is the engaging diameter (Transverse diameter) in cephalic presentation; it measures 9.5 cm
  • Option B: Suboccipitobregmatic diameter: This is the presenting diameter in a well flexed head; it measures 9.5 cm.
  • Option C: Occipito-frontal diameter: This is the presenting diameter in a deflexed head. It measures 11.5 cm

 

Educational Objective:

 

DIAMETERS OF FETAL SKULL

 

 

Ref: Page no 92 Textbook of obstetrics by JB Sharma

choices.text: Transverse diameter of inlet is 10 cm.
AP diameter of inlet is 12 cm

questions.text: One of the following features can be used to define contracted pelvis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Transverse diameter of inlet is 10 cm

 

Normal pelvic diameters

 

 

TC: True conjugate

 

OC: Obstetric conjugate

 

DC: Diagonal conjugate

 

In contracted pelvis

 

Inlet:

 

  1. Obstetric conjugate < 10 cm
  2. Transverse diameter < 12 cm (in the question it is given Transverse diameter < 10 cm)

 

Mid-pelvis:

 

  1. Contraction suspected if interspinous diameter < 10 cm
    100% confirmed contracted pelvis if interspinous diameter < 8 cm
  2. (Sum of interspinous diameter and posterior sagittal diameter is < 13.5 cm

 

Outlet:

 

  1. If interspinous diameter < 8 cm
  2. (Sum of bi-tuberous and posterior sagittal diameter of outlet is < 15 cm

 

Educational Objective:

 

 In contracted pelvis

 

Inlet:

 

  1. Obstetric conjugate < 10 cm
  2. Transverse diameter < 12 cm (in the question it is given Transverse diameter < 10 cm)

 

Mid-pelvis:

 

  1. Contraction suspected if interspinous diameter < 10 cm 100% confirmed contracted pelvis if interspinous diameter < 8 cm
  2. (Sum of interspinous diameter and posterior sagittal diameter is < 13.5 cm

 

Outlet:

 

  1. If interspinous diameter < 8 cm
  2. (Sum of bi-tuberous and posterior sagittal diameter of outlet is < 15 cm

 

Ref: Page no 92 Textbook of obstetrics by JB Sharma

choices.text: Incidence is about 7% at term pregnancy
More common in postdated pregnancy
More in pelvic anomalies
External cephalic version increases incidence of breech presentation

questions.text: True about breech presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. More in pelvic anomalies

 

Let’s discuss all the options

 

  • Option A: The incidence of breech at term is 3-4% (At 28 weeks it is 25%)
  • Option B: Breech is more common in preterm pregnancies. At term, the incidence of breech is only 3% as compared to 25% at 28 weeks.
  • Option C: Breech presentation is more common in pelvic abnormalities and in Mullerian anomalies
  • Option D: External cephalic version decreases the incidence of breech presentation as it is done in women with breech or transverse lie in order to turn them to a cephalic presentation to achieve a vaginal delivery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The incidence of breech at term is 3-4% (At 28 weeks it is 25%)
  • Etiology of Breech Presentation
    • Prematurity: MC cause
    • Factor preventing spontaneous version: Breech with extended legs, twins, Oligohydramnios; Congenital malformation of uterus such as septate or  bicornuate uterus; Short cord & IUD of the fetus
    • Favourable adaptation: Hydrocephalous; Placenta previa Contracted pelvis &Cornu-fundal attachment of the placenta
    • Undue mobility of fetus: Hydramnios & Multipara with lax abdominal wall
    • Fetal abnormalities: Trisomy 13, 18, 21; Anencephaly &myotonic dystrophy due to alternation of fetal muscular tone & mobility
       
  • External Cephalic Version
    • It has been considered from 36 weeks
    • Success rate of version is about 50-60%
    • Benefit
      • Reduction in the incidence of breech presentation at term
      • Reduction in the incidence of breech delivery & associated complication.
      • Reduction in the incidence of caesarean section

 

Ref: Page no 323 Textbook of obstetrics by JB Sharma

questions.text: Head delivery by flexion occurs in?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Face presentation

 

Let’s Discuss all the Options

 

  • Option A: Brown presentation: There is NO mechanism of labor in brow and in mento-posterior positions
  • Option B: Face presentation: In face presentation (mento-anterior) , in mechanism of labor, the head is born by flexion
  • Option C: In Occipito-posterior, the head is born by face to pubis if it undergoes short arc rotation
  • Option D: Occipito anterior: The head is born by Extension in a flexed or deflexed head (OA or OP)

 

Thus, option B) Face presentation is true.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Remember

 

  • The head is born by Extension in a flexed or deflexed head (OA or OP)
  • In Occipito-posterior, the head is born by face to pubis if it undergoes short arc rotation
  • In face presentation (mento-anterior) , in mechanism of labor, the head is born by flexion
  • There is NO mechanism of labor in brow and in mento-posterior positions

 

Ref: Page no 308 Textbook of obstetrics by JB Sharma

choices.text: A gynecoid pelvis
An android pelvis
An anthropoid pelvis
A platypelloid pelvis

questions.text: A patient presents in labor at term. Clinical pelvimetry is performed. She has an oval-shaped pelvis with antero-posterior diameter at the inlet more than the transverse diameter. On abdominal examination, there is sub-umbilical flattening, and the fetal heart is auscultated on the flanks. The most likely kind of pelvis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. An anthropoid pelvis

 

  • The scenario described above is an occipito posterior position
  • An occipito posterior position is most commonly associated with an anthropoid pelvis

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Page no 90, Textbook of Obstetrics by JB Sharma

questions.text: In the pelvic inlet, which is the shortest anteroposterior diameter?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Obstetric conjugate

 

  • The obstetric conjugate is the shortest antero-posterior diameter of the pelvic inlet and measures 10 cm.

 

Other options

 

  • Option A: True conjugate: True (anatomical) conjugate (11 cm): Extends from uppermost margin of symphysis pubis to the sacral promontory.
  • Option C: Anatomical conjugate: This is another name for the true conjugate: Extends from uppermost margin of symphysis pubis to the sacral promontory. It measures 11 cm.
  • Option D: Bispinous diameter (10 cms) is the transverse diameter of the mid-pelvis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diameters of the Pelvic Inlet

 

Anteroposterior (AP) Diameter

 

  • True (anatomical) conjugate (11 cm): Extends from uppermost margin of symphysis pubis to the sacral promontory.
  • Obstetric conjugate (10 cm): It is the shortest AP diameter of the pelvic inlet and hence obstetrically most important. It is measured from the middle of sacral promontory to symphysis pubis. It cannot be measured directly on clinical examination. It is calculated by subtracting 1.5 cm from diagonal conjugate.
  • Diagonal conjugate (12.5 cm): It is measured from tip of sacral promontory to the lower margin of pubic symphysis. It is the only diameter that can be assessed clinically.

 

Transverse Diameter (13 cm)

 

  • Distance between the farthest two points on the iliopectineal line.
  • It is the largest diameter of pelvic inlet

 

Oblique Diameters (12 cm)

 

  • Right oblique diameter: Passes from right sacroiliac joint to left ilio-pubiceminence
  • Left oblique diameter: Passes from left sacroiliac joint to right ilio-pubic eminence

 

Ref: Page no 92 Textbook of obstetrics by JB Sharma

questions.text: After delivery, a mother notices a swelling on the baby’s head in the occipital region. The pediatrician tells her it is caput succedaneum and will disappear by itself. She is very concerned and asks you, the resident, how long it will take to resolve?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Within 24–48 hours

 

  • A caput succedaneum usually disappears within 24-48h of birth.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Page no 92, Textbook of Obstetrics by JB Sharma, 3rd edition

choices.text: All are equal in length

questions.text: The shortest transverse diameter of the fetus is?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Bimastoid diameter

 

  • The shortest transverse diameter of the fetus is the mastoid diameter

 

Other Options:

 

  • Biparietal diameter: This measures 9.5cm
  • Bitemporal diameter: This measures 8cm

           

Educational Objective:

 

DIAMETERS OF FETAL SKULL

 

 

Ref: Page no 92 Textbook of obstetrics by JB Sharma

questions.text: The presenting diameter of a fully flexed head is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Suboccipito-bregmatic diameter

 

  • The presenting diameter of a fully flexed head is sub-occipito bregmatic diameter. This measures 9.5 cm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DIAMETERS OF FETAL SKULL

 

 

 

Some Important Points

 

  • Normal female pelvis is–Gynecoid pelvis
  • Male type pelvis is–Android pelvis
  • M/c type of pelvis–Gynecoid pelvis
  • Least common type pelvis–Platypelloid pelvis
  • The pelvis with AP diameter more than transverse diameter–Anthropoid pelvis
  • Occipito–Posterior position is m/c associated with Anthropoid pelvis
  • Face to pubis delivery is most common in anthropoid pelvis
  • Broad flat pelvis–Platypelloid pelvis
  • The pelvic inlet usually is contracted if its shortest anteroposterior diameter is less than 10 cm or if the greatest transverse diameter is less than 12 cm.

 

Ref: Page no 92 Textbook of obstetrics by JB Sharma

questions.text: If the lower most portion of presenting fetal part at ischial spine, it means the station is at?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 0

 

  • Station of fetal head: These are described with respect to the ischial spine (0 station) as shown in the diagram below
  • At 0 station, the head is at the level of the ishial spines
  • If above the spines, it is denoted by ‘minus’
  • If below the spines, it is denoted by ‘plus’

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Station of fetal head: These are described with respect to the ischial spine (0 station) as shown in the diagram below
  • At 0 station, the head is at the level of the ishial spines
  • If above the spines, it is denoted by ‘minus’
  • If below the spines, it is denoted by ‘plus’

 

 

Ref: Page no 89, JB Sharma’s Textbook of Obstetrics 3rd edition

questions.text: Which pelvic dimension is being measured in the image shown below?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Diagonal conjugate

 

  • Diagonal conjugate is the only pelvic dimension that can be measured clinically.
  • It is as shown and is the distance between the lower edge of the pubic symphysis to the sacral promontory
  • By subtracting 1.5 cm from the diagonal conjugate, we get the obstetric conjugate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Page no 88, Textbook of Obstetrics, JB Sharma 3rd edition

questions.text: Match the following fetal head diameters with their numeric values:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 1-B, 2-D, 3-C, 4-A

 

Educational Objective:

 

DIAMETERS OF FETAL SKULL
